questions.question_text:
A customer wants to deploy VMware Horizon View to support virtual desktops hosted in two different physical locations and wants users to connect to the location nearest them to start a session.
Which three steps must be completed to enable this functionality? (Choose three.)

choices.D: Configure one View Pod spanning two sites.

discussion.content: BCF. You need a Global Entitlement to use the 'nearest pod' feature and in Horizon 7 you do not need Events databases for it to work. The databases are needed for health and monitoring but not 'required' It is true that you need one database per pod as they don't share between pods.

Funny how there is another question worded exactly the same and the answer is One pod spanning two sites. Global entitlements not an answer either.
However, I beleive NNy here is correct as they are in most cases.
BCF makes the most sense.

discussion.content: Careful with the question. Assignments are to be 'User Based' which rules out Thin App unless you are using Identity Manager. ABF in this case 'App Volumes' over Thin App

questions.question_text:
During a planning meeting for an upcoming deployment of a Horizon View 7.1 environments, these requirements were identified by an architect:
✑ Separate pools for internal and external connectivity.
✑ Applications are not to be installed in the desktop VMs.
✑ Application assignments are to be user-based.
✑ No VPN is to be used.
Which three should the architect recommend to meet the requirements? (Choose three.)

choices.C: Use ThinApp to stream the applications.
choices.A: Use VMware Horizon View's tagging feature to identify external / internal pools.
choices.D: Use VMware User Environment Manager to define network subnets that will filter the lists of external / internal desktop pools based on the user's client ip address.
choices.E: Use VMware NSX and deploy micro-segmentation rules that will filter the lists of external / internal desktop pools based on the user's client ip address.
